articles.headline: Anchor’s Ties to Citigroup Attract Scrutiny
articles.snippet: A recent conflict with Citigroup has raised questions about the judgment of Maria Bartiromo, the popular CNBC anchor, in getting too close to the people she covers.
articles.abstract: A recent conflict with Citigroup has raised questions about the judgment of Maria Bartiromo, the popular CNBC anchor, in getting too close to the people she covers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Late last year, an executive from Citigroup phoned an official connected with CNBC, the cable business news channel. According to people with knowledge of the call, the Citigroup executive made it clear that Maria Bartiromo, the popular CNBC anchor, would not be permitted to fly on Citigroup’s corporate jet again.

articles.headline: Iraq Leader and Sunni Officials in Clash on Security
articles.snippet: The sectarian confrontation came as Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki is under increasing pressure to demonstrate evenhandedness.
articles.abstract: The sectarian confrontation came as Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki is under increasing pressure to demonstrate evenhandedness.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Jan. 25 — Iraq’s Shiite prime minister and Sunni lawmakers hurled insults at one another during a raucous session of Parliament on Thursday, with the prime minister threatening a Sunni lawmaker with arrest and the Sunni speaker of Parliament threatening to quit.

articles.headline: Delays Limit Robust Sales at Microsoft
articles.snippet: Microsoft reported strong sales but its financial results were muddled by the late arrival of important new products.
articles.abstract: Microsoft reported strong sales but its financial results were muddled by the late arrival of important new products.
articles.lead_paragraph: Microsoft yesterday reported strong sales for its latest quarter and a profit that slightly surpassed Wall Street estimates, but its financial results were muddled by the late arrival of important new products.

articles.headline: No Frivolity: Davos Tries Fewer Stars
articles.snippet: Davos is devoid this year of the Hollywood crowd and their pet causes that have previously given the event a bit of extra gloss.
articles.abstract: Davos is devoid this year of the Hollywood crowd and their pet causes that have previously given the event a bit of extra gloss.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 25 — Snow was not the only thing in short supply as moguls and world leaders rolled into this ski resort town this week.

articles.headline: Fearing Protectionism, in India
articles.snippet: In India, the growth has come, and with it concern about unequal distribution.
articles.abstract: In India, the growth has come, and with it concern about unequal distribution.

articles.headline: Hollywood, the Sequel: Less Shabby, More Chic
articles.snippet: A famous intersection in Los Angeles — Hollywood and Vine — seems to have finally achieved a comeback.
articles.abstract: A famous intersection in Los Angeles — Hollywood and Vine — seems to have finally achieved a comeback.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25 — For decades, tourists deposited themselves at one of the most famous intersections in America — Hollywood and Vine — and looked around in puzzlement, wondering what exactly they were supposed to be seeing.

articles.headline: Ford Chief Sees Small as Virtue and Necessity
articles.snippet: The bigger-is-better worldview that has defined Ford is being replaced with a new one: less is more.
articles.abstract: The bigger-is-better worldview that has defined Ford is being replaced with a new one: less is more.
articles.lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich., Jan. 25 — Just 10 months ago, William Clay Ford Jr. vowed that his auto company, despite its mounting losses, would “reclaim our legacy” in the American car market and “emerge stronger than we’ve ever been.”

articles.headline: Tremors at the Door
articles.snippet: The once booming market for home loans to people with weak credit is now coming under greater pressure.
articles.abstract: The once booming market for home loans to people with weak credit is now coming under greater pressure.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s big bet on risky mortgages may be souring a lot faster than had been previously thought.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Christine Haughney
